steps.name: match $.data.user.posts.data[0] contains { id: '1' }
comments: # json-path makes it easy to focus only on the parts you are interested in
# which is especially useful for graph-ql as responses tend to be heavily nested
# '$' happens to be a JsonPath-friendly short-cut for the 'response' variable

steps.name: def posts = $..posts.data[*]
comments: # the '..' wildcard is useful for traversing deeply nested parts of the json

steps.name: match posts[1] == { id: '2', title: 'qui est esse' }

elements.name: graphql query from a file and using examples - Bret

steps.name: def query = read('./queries/user-by-id.graphql')
comments: # here the query is read from a file
# note that the 'replace' keyword (not used here) can also be very useful for dynamic query building
